I looked at it (fresh 0.1.55) and it shows promise:
1) It doesn't automatically recognize bash language.  It does if the file is a .sh.  This case (https://github.com/sinelaw/fresh/issues/383#event-21655849895) apparently addresses this issue.
2) The colors aren't great but maybe I just don't know enough yet.
3) Copy/paste appears to work correctly.
4) It is written in rust vs micro being written in golang.

It can do multiple (unlimited?) levels of subtasks. It has notes.  It has tags but does not have lists.  It has priority (9-6 low, 5 medium, 4-1 high, 0 no priority).  It has field for setting percent complete.
Repeating tasks are not supported in the web interface but they are supported in the backend and Tasks.org supports creating these.
Tasks also appear as a pane in the calendar (collapsible).  The "visibility of smart collections" can be set -- not sure what this is.

There is no direct handler to import exported RTM tasks into Tasks.org.  RTM produces a JSON iCal (.ics) file.  Tasks.org doesn't understand this but can accept a CSV.  Some kind of conversion program would be needed.
I installed the Tasks.org app on phone, created a test task (with multiple sub-tasks four deep), and set up DAVx to sync tasks.  It is working.  Need to play with it to see.
Access to files (ala DropBox).  Calendar and Contacts are via whatever apps are installed for that.
I am now relying upon Nextcloud calendar and just duplicating entries for now so Karen can see them and I can see hers.

2026-01-20
I updated the calendar, updated Karen's calendar, shared all in between.
Then I set my phone to sync with DAVx calendar and disabled Google calendars.

I just tried to edit "Interstellar - Our Place in the Dirt.txt" and found no way to do it on NC.  So, I downloaded it, edited and saved it, then dragged and dropped it again to NC.  But it didn't update the file?  I tried twice to view it and it was always the same as the original.  So, I deleted that one, and uploaded the new one and that worked.  Strange...
I was successful doing this and added an entry in Joplin: joplin://x-callback-url/openNote?id=e76fb68735844fa391619bb0e937dd2a

This article was the key to what appears to be success.
https://github.com/nextcloud/all-in-one/discussions/5939

I think we are on to something here.  I think it is set up correctly, I just need to do some failed login testing to confirm.

Watch the logs via "sudo tail -f /var/lib/docker/volumes/nextcloud_aio_nextcloud/_data/data/nextcloud.log".  This is the path which fail2ban is watching.  It is the file system exposed logs which are the same ones viewed within the container via "tail -f /var/www/html/data/nextcloud.log"

Make several failed logins.  Nextcloud will display a "Too many attempts" after about 6-10 failures.  It  may take 5 or as many as 30 minutes to clear.

But it can be forced.

Installed the Nextcloud desktop app, added in Documents the folders for Church and Reference which I've been using in DropBox.  Added this as a shared folder and it works great.  Nextcloud desktop app supports selective sync.

I downloaded the photos from 2025 PNWGT and 2025 Ride Photos then uploaded all of these to the /Photos folder.  When I attempt to add photos to a folder, there are two that do not appear.  If I select "Photos" and scroll to the bottom, I see two photos under the January 2025 heading.  Yet, when I go to "Albums", create and album, and "Add photos", then scroll tot he bottom, those pictures do not appear.  The list ends with the March 2025 photos.

I submitted a bug: https://github.com/nextcloud/photos/issues/3365

Not very pleased.  It does provide an album but it is really basic.  You can create albums and collaborative (shared?) albums but cannot organize the photos in the album; i.e., they are listed only in date order.  That sort order is pointless and arbitrary.

Had a conversation with Grok: https://grok.com/share/c2hhcmQtMg%3D%3D_88084a23-583f-4653-a8f3-980b71920f10

Because of this, I renamed the folder/repository to fs_tools instead of cz_tools.

It is using requiring the install of fsarchiver, gdisk, whiptail.  The latter is a text-based UI interaction app.  Not sure I want to use that; I like just working at the command-line.  But it is nice that it easily supports multiple selection.
There isn't enough space gained (~100MB) by removing unnecessary packages to make it worth doing.  I have both recovery partitions set to 5GB and that is not worth worrying about.

I asked Grok "If I were to remove all the package listed on this page (https://wiki.debian.org/ReduceDebian#Remove_non-critical_packages) from a standard Debian install (which has no GUI installed and no web server), can you determine how much total space would be saved?"

He replied: "The space saved by removing the non-critical packages identified via the command in the wiki's "Remove non-critical packages" section (after also running the subsequent apt-get purge aptitude, apt-get autoremove, and apt-get clean steps) would be approximately 100 MB on a fresh minimal Debian 12 server installation. This estimate is based on comparisons of disk usage in equivalent setups before and after similar optimizations, assuming an amd64 architecture. Note that exact savings can vary slightly depending on the specific Debian version, architecture, and any dependencies that get autoremoved."

Doing `df -H` it shows that the recovery partition (/deb/sda4) is 8.2G of which only 1.4G is used.

Should I just build a Debian install on a USB and use that instead of a separate recovery partition?  Why wouldn't that work?

Won't work because it wouldn't be in the grub menu and a command run on the main partition (e.g., recovery-reboot) couldn't set it up to boot to that USB drive.  Grub only has entries from the local drive.

Grok's response: https://grok.com/c/9513bac1-543c-47d2-b2be-b7ace118c92d

Per conversation with Grok, I added a function/alias to .bashrc on brawn and this is working to change the colors.  But, it means: 1) the prompt still has to be set on the remote system, and 2) that the changes to .bashrc have to be made to any system that is going to ssh to the server.

After upgrade, need to get rid of older kernels.  Probably best to keep the last three(?) but get rid of any older.  The tool could allow specifying the number to keep.

dpkg -l | grep -E 'linux-image-[0-9]' | awk '{print $2" "$3}' | cut -d' ' -f1
linux-image-6.12.43+deb13-amd64
linux-image-6.12.48+deb13-amd64
linux-image-6.12.57+deb13-amd64

If the list is more than the limit:
sudo apt purge linux-image-6.6.15-amd64 linux-headers-6.6.15-amd64
sudo rm /boot/vmlinuz-6.6.15-amd64* /boot/initrd.img-6.6.15-amd64

update-grub

sudo apt autoremove
sudo apt autoclean

This command will list all but the latest two -- so, a list of those to be deleted?
dpkg -l | grep -E 'linux-(image|headers)-[0-9]' | awk '{print $2}' | grep -v "$(uname -r)" | sort -V | head -n -1

After upgrade on recovery-partition, update-grub must be run to pick up the kernel changes and continue having recovery-reboot boot into the latest kernel on recovery.

How can I code the tool so that it only does the update-grub on the recovery?  Does it already do it on the main?  It must because it booted into the new kernel.  But maybe running it regardless doesn't hurt?
